title: 〜らしい
meaning: I hear that...; apparently...; it seems that...
how_to_use: Used for conjecture based on hearsay.
This form can only be used at the end of a sentence.

examples.meaning:
A: This homework, it took as much as 3 hours! Even though it was only one page.
Really, that much?
C: That homework is difficult, apparently.

text.spelling:
A：この{宿題|しゅく・だい}、３{時間|じ・かん}もかかったよ。
１ページだけだったのに……。
B：ええっ、そんなに！
C：あの{宿題|しゅく・だい}はとても{難|むずか}しいらしい。

examples.meaning:
A: As for next semester, I'm thinking I'll live in the dorm.
From Yui-senpai I heard, that place, every week has parties and is lively, apparently!

text.spelling:
A：{来学期|らい・がっ・き}は{寮|りょう}に{住|す}もうと{思|おも}っているんだ。
Ｂ：{唯|ゆい}{先輩|せん・ぱい}から{聞|き}いたんだけど、あそこは{毎週|まい・しゅう}パーティーがあって、{賑|にぎ}やからしいよ。

examples.meaning: According to rumor, those two will get married it seems.

text.spelling: {噂|うわさ}では、あの{二人|ふたり}は{結婚|けっ・こん}するらしい。

title: ＡはＢらしい
meaning: A is a perfect example of B.
how_to_use: noun + は + noun + らしい
Nらしい conjugates as an い-adj.

examples.meaning:
A: Today the weather is good.
Truly. It's warm and stereotypically spring like.

text.spelling:
Ａ：{今日|きょう}はいい{天気|てん・き}ですね。
Ｂ：{本当|ほん・とう}に。{暖|あたた}かくて{春|はる}らしいですね。

examples.meaning: Today, it's warm and not typical winter like.

text.spelling: {今日|きょう}は{暖|あたた}かくて{冬|ふゆ}らしくない{天気|てん・き}だ。

examples.meaning: My dog doesn't like walks, and is not dog-like.

text.spelling: うちの{犬|いぬ}は{散歩|さん・ぽ}が{嫌|きら}いで、{犬|いぬ}らしくない。

examples.meaning:
Child: I'm leaving.
Mom: Again your job? If you are a student, in a student-like way (adverb) study (command).

text.spelling:
{子|こ}：いってきます。
{母|はは}：またバイト？{学生|がく・せい}なら{学生|がく・せい}らしく{勉強|べん・きょう}しなさい。
